Title.evidence: The Effect of Popliteus Tendon Resection on Knee Stability in Total Knee Arthroplasty: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to Group A (n=9), where the popliteus tendon was resected, or Group B (n=9), where it was preserved.

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included patients scheduled for primary TKA.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to Group A (n=9), where the popliteus tendon was resected, or Group B (n=9), where it was preserved.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the effects of popliteus tendon resection on knee ligament balancing and load distribution during TKA.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was knee stability, evaluated intraoperatively by a blinded senior surgeon.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with concealed allocation.

Blinding.evidence: The primary outcome was knee stability, evaluated intraoperatively by a blinded senior surgeon.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to Group A (n=9), where the popliteus tendon was resected, or Group B (n=9), where it was preserved.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis followed a per-protocol approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The senior surgeon found no difference in knee stability between the groups.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
